content.description: Excellent and varied climbing up the face and dihedral.  Start up the face past thin moves and a small overlap to gain a slabby section.  Climb up and right towards the roofed dihedral.  Intensely tricky climbing leads up the dihedral and over the roof to the anchors.  A must do.
Climb the crack just left of "For Patricia".  Go left to the anchor of "Sparky the Drillhead".  A decent little crack climb.
content.location: The crack just left of "For Patricia".

content.description:
This is a fine finger and hand crack that pulls a really fun roof.

Although trad routes aren't typically allowed by the DWP, this one has so far slipped the staff's notice.  Don't let that stop you, it is well protected with gear and offers secure finger and hand jams with plenty of good face holds.
content.protection: Set of stoppers, tcu's, and cams to 2-1/2", more fingers than hands.  Lower off anchor on Kelly's Heroes.
content.location: This is the prominent hand crack through the roof left of Walk the Yellow line.

climbs.name: Stella
climbs.fa: Dana Drucker, Mike Strassman, L. Drucker, T. Drucker, 1990, GU

content.description: I gave this route the 5.8+ rating because the beginning (if you avoid the right crack holds) is the crux of the route...the rest is straightforward pocket pulling.

A very nice off vertical technical face climb.  Great rock and well protected.

Pull past the first two bolts to great holds then another crux at the last bolt where you can decide to make a long move left or a couple of crimps right.
content.protection: Seven bolts - lower off anchor hooks.
content.location: This is the leftmost route accessed from the belay ledge with bolts used for Frank and For Patricia.

content.description: This is the slanting arete just to the climber's right of Walk the Yellow Line.  Make your way up towards the arete and the thin crack.  Crack the code, hit the jug and hold it together for a few more moves.
content.location: Upper Elbow Room, just to the climber's right of Walk the Yellow Line.

content.description: The route starts as a left-leaning ramp that tries to push you off.  The crux comes as the holds get thinner making for some interesting slabby/balancy moves.  Then there is a short section of crack that one must at some point abandon to climb the bolted face and reach the anchors.
content.location: Down and left from the main Upper Elbow Room crag.  Always shady in the winter.

content.description:
This is a fun climb with a thin face start, a jug haul roof and nice face climbing along a finger crack above.

This route is now sport bolted and is well protected.

A little contrived on the lower face past fun climbing, but the roof is a kick in the pants.
content.protection: 7 new bolts - lower off.  No trad gear needed.
content.location: This is the right of two cracks splitting a cool roof, just left of Walk the Yellow Line.  It starts up a thin face, right of the Stella's Fella crack.

content.description:
Technical face to a nice steep hand crack behind a flake.  It then joins Post Partum for the last three bolts.

This one should probably have two ratings.  10d for following the bolt line religiously, or 10b for climbing to the left.  It is very easy to skip the crux by climbing to a ledge after the first bolt, then back right.
content.location: Starts about 20 feet left of Post Partum.

content.description: the PG13 rating comes from the last section (from the last bolt to the anchors is like 20+ feet)
content.location:
Just left of

Frank

.  Shares the same lower off as

Frank

.

content.description: One of the better Cordner routes, like many of his lines, it features atypical for ORG devious climbing through off vertical terrain.  The crux is two or three bolts before the anchors.
content.location: Starts at a bolted fracture about 5M downhill of Walk the Yellow Line.
